q2.value: Gregory Rousis, Jennifer Bosson, Roxanne Felig

q3.value:
This is an additional study for a previously pre-registered project (link to the previous pre-registration is https://osf.io/d3up6). Ambivalent sexism theory posits that sexism is composed of two dimensions that are positively correlated: hostile and benevolent sexism. Hostile sexism is composed of traditionally misogynistic views of women, whereas benevolent sexism is made up of subjectively positive, but nonetheless, patronizing views of women. However, in 23 extant, unpublished data sets we found that a curvilinear relationship between these two variables provides a better explanation of the data. Our findings suggest that men high in hostile sexism express lower levels of benevolent sexism than predicted by Ambivalent Sexism theory - what we call "unambivalent sexism." 

Following this, we conducted a pre-registered confirmatory study with the expectation that dyadic social status (operationalized as perceived mate value) and structural social status (operationalized as self-perceived social status) would moderate this effect, such that low-status men would evince the curvilinear HS-BS relationship, whereas higher status men would not. A study of 328 participants revealed that only dyadic social status – and not structural social status – helps explain the presence of this relationship. We found the expected interaction: For men high in dyadic status, hostile and benevolent sexism were linearly related, but for men low in dyadic status, hostile and benevolent sexism were curvilinearly associated (an inverted-U pattern). Moreover, at high levels of hostile sexism, men with low dyadic status reported lower benevolent sexism than those with higher dyadic status. In other words, men low in perceived mate value displayed relatively unambivalent, hostile sexism. However, two issues arose from this study: we did not predict nor measure a potential mechanism underlying this relationship, and structural social status did not moderate the curvilinear moderation as we expected.

The present study seeks to expand on these findings by: (a) replicating the curvilinear hostile sexism-by-perceived mate value interaction on benevolent sexism, (b) examining a mechanism underlying this moderated effect, and (c) testing again for the curvilinear hostile sexism-by-structural status interaction. The test of curvilinear moderated mediation (b) is exploratory, and will include tests of several possible mechanisms (pessimism about finding a relationship partner, resentful beliefs about dating, resentment of unattainable women). The test of the curvilinear hostile sexism-by-structural status interaction (c) is also exploratory, because we did not find it in our prior confirmatory test (but had a theoretical reason to test it).

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1
H1a. There will be a significant positive linear association between hostile and benevolent sexism.
H1b. This positive linear association will remain significant when relevant covariates are included in the model.

Hypothesis 2
H2a. There will be a significant, upside-down U-shaped curvilinear relationship between hostile and benevolent sexism, such that as hostile sexism increases, benevolent sexism increases up to a point, then flattens and/or reverses (when controlling for the linear effect tested in H1a).
H2b. This curvilinear association will remain significant when relevant covariates are included in the model.

Hypothesis 3
H3a. There will a quadratic two-way interaction of HS-squared x dyadic status (perceived mate value) predicting BS.
H3b. Among men high in hostile sexism (e.g., +1 SD above the mean), those low in dyadic status (e.g., -1 SD below the mean) will report significantly lower benevolent sexism than those high in dyadic status (e.g., +1 SD above the mean).
H3c. These effects (the quadratic two-way interaction [H3a] and the simple effect [H3b]) will remain significant when relevant covariates are included in the model.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We are using a cross-sectional between-subjects design. We will counterbalance the order in which participants complete measures of sexism versus status. We will randomize the presentation of administration of all status scales (within the block of status measures) as well as the presentation of items within most scales. The exploratory mediators will be presented after the randomized blocks and before demographics.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Amazon's Mechanical Turk software and will be paid $1.00 for survey completion. Participants must be heterosexual men between the ages of 18 and 50 who currently reside in the United States.

q13.value: We will be collecting data from at least 600 participants.

q14.value: We conducted power analysis using the simsem package (Jorgensen, Pornprasertmanit, Miller, & Schoemann, 2018) in R. This indicated that we would need approximately 800 participants to reliably detect the indirect moderated mediation effect. However, given financial constraints, we are not sure if we can afford to collect data from more than 600 participants.

q15.value: We will post this survey on Amazon's Mechanical Turk in batches of nine. As one batch is finished, a new one will be posted until we have 600 participants who completed the survey, including correctly answering all attention checks.

question.value: N/A
See attached document.

Hostile and Benevolent Sexism scores will be computed by averaging across the 11 items that comprise each subscale, after reverse coding relevant items.

Subjective dyadic status will be computed by averaging across 20 of the 22 items of the Perceived Mate Value scale, after reverse coding relevant items. This index will exclude items in the scale that constitute the “Wealth” subscale, as we are measuring wealth using different measures described below.

Objective dyadic status will be computed as a regression-based factor score of the 4 relationship questions described in the document above. 

Exploratory Indices
Pessimism about finding a relationship partner, an exploratory mediator, will be computed by averaging across the 3 items in the scale.

Resentful beliefs about dating, an exploratory mediator, will be computed by averaging across the 3 items in the scale.

Resentment of unattainable women, an exploratory mediator, will be computed by averaging across the 4 items in the scale.

We will also conduct exploratory factor analyses on the items that comprise the 3 exploratory mediators listed above. The items that load on a single factor will be combined using a regression-based factor score for use in the curvilinear moderated mediation model.

Subjective structural status, which will be used in exploratory analyses, will be computed as an average of z-scores of 2 scales with 4 items total: self-perceived social status and the status ladder scales. 

Objective structural status, which will be used in exploratory analyses, will be computed as an average z-score of participant’s highest level of education, participant’s current income, and the income of the household in which participants were raised.
See attached document.

q20.value: The categorical demographic variables that will be examined as possible covariates will be dummy-coded. The reference group for race will be non-White participants, and for ethnicity, non-Hispanic participants. We will grand mean-center hostile sexism in order to correct for multicollinearity in the interaction terms.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 inference criteria to infer statistical significance for the regression analyses. We will also be using the index of conditional partial moderated mediation available in the PROCESS macro for SPSS (Hayes, 2013). This estimates a 95% confidence interval around the partial moderated mediation effect, which indicates a statistically significant effect if it does not cross 0.

q22.value:
Attention checks will be interspersed throughout the survey, and participants who fail to answer any of them correctly will be excluded from the data. In addition, if a participant completes the survey, but discloses that they do not meet the inclusion criteria (heterosexual male between the ages of 18 and 50 currently residing in the United States), their data will be excluded. 

We will use the following criteria to remove outliers in the data: 
1. Criterion for determining univariate outliers is greater than 3 standard deviations from the scale’s mean 
2. Criteria for determining multivariate outliers are Mahalanobis distance and Cook’s distance.

q23.value: Incomplete or missing data will be excluded from the analyses on a casewise basis.

q24.value:
1.	We will validate the curvilinear relationship (H2a) by employing the 2-Lines approach to non-linear data (Simonsohn, 2018), which allows for the computation of two regression lines at high and low values of HS. We expect that the coefficient of BS regressed onto HS will be positive and significant until slightly above the HS scale midpoint, at which point it will either plateau and become non-significant, or reverse and become significantly negative.

2.	Will the 10 items assessing pessimism about finding a relationship partner, resentful beliefs about dating, and resentment of unattainable women load onto the same dimension?
    a.	To test the intercorrelations between these items, we will conduct an exploratory principal axis factor analysis with an oblique rotation.
    b.	Given the results of this EFA, we may create a regression-based mean of these items as a single mediator, use multiple dimensions as mediators, or use each scale on its own in separate mediation analyses.

3.	Will pessimism about finding a relationship partner, resentful beliefs about dating, resentment of unattainable women, or some combination of these constructs mediate the curvilinear HS2 x PMV interaction on BS?
    a.	To test this curvilinear moderated mediation model, we will use models 9 and 10 from the PROCESS macro in SPSS (Hayes, 2013). However, if inspection of the correlations among variables indicates that another model is more suitable, we may use a different moderated mediation model in PROCESS.
    b.	We have already established a curvilinear HS x PMV interaction on BS, and these models allows us to predict that relationship while also establishing pessimism/resentment as a mediating mechanism.
    c.	        We will use the index of moderated mediation as the test of significance. If the confidence interval does not cross zero, we will conclude that there is an indirect effect of the HS-squared x PMV interaction on BS via men’s pessimism/resentment towards dating and women. 
    d.	If the confidence interval for the index of moderated mediation does not cross zero, we will conduct pick-a-point analyses (at -1 SD, the mean, and +1 SD) to determine where along the HS continuum men’s PMV causes resentment/pessimism and hence, BS.

4.	Is subjective structural status a moderator of the curvilinear relationship between HS and BS?
    a.	To test the curvilinear moderation model, we will conduct a hierarchical regression analysis by regressing BS onto:
    b.	HS and subjective structural status (in Step 1);
    c.	        HS2 and the HS x subjective structural status interaction term (in Step 2); and
    d.	the HS2 x subjective structural status interaction term (in Step 3).
 
5.	If a significant HS2 x subjective structural status interaction emerges at Step 3, we will conduct follow-up simple effects tests examining the association of subjective structural status on BS among men high in HS.  Specifically, at high levels of HS, we expect men low in subjective structural status to report lower BS than men high in subjective structural status. We will operationalize “high in HS” as one standard deviation above the sample mean on HS (unless inspection of the data reveals that this is inappropriate, e.g., the value at +1 SD is above the range of possible scale values, in which case we will select an appropriate value to represent high scores on HS).

6.	If the above interaction is statistically significant, will it hold when controlling for the relevant covariates (e.g., age, race, ethnicity)?

7.	If the above interaction is statistically significant, will pessimism about gaining social status, resentful beliefs about social status, resentment of unattainable social status, or some combination of these constructs mediate the curvilinear HS2 x subjective structural status interaction on BS?
    a.	To test this curvilinear moderated mediation model, we will use models 9 and 10 from the PROCESS macro in SPSS (Hayes, 2013). However, if inspection of the correlations among variables indicates that another model is more suitable, we may use a different moderated mediation model in PROCESS.

8.	How do demographic variables affect the curvilinear relationship between HS and BS?
    a.	If any demographic variables do moderate the curvilinear effect of HS on BS, we will decompose the effects by regressing BS onto:
       i.	HS, status, and demographics in step 1
       ii.	HS2, HS x status, and status x demographics in step 2
       iii.	HS2 x status and HS2 x demographics in step 3
       iv.	HS2 x status x demographics in step 4

summary.value:
We will conduct a re-analysis of the Manylabs 4 project (Klein et al., 2019) using Bayesian meta-analytic techniques and multilevel modeling. There has been some debate about the preregistered exclusion criteria leading to a comment on the original manuscript by Chatard, Hirschberger, and Pyszczynski (2020). Our reanalysis will therefore explore the effects of four different exclusion criteria. 

See document for analysis details.

attributes.title: Health Professions Opportunity Grants 2.0 Evaluation, Short-Term Impact Report and Cost Benefit Analysis

summary.value:
The objective of the HPOG 2.0 Impact Evaluation is to determine whether the collection of programs administered by the 27 non-tribal HPOG 2.0 grantees led to higher levels of educational progress, earnings, and career-track employment for the students they served than those individuals would have been able to achieve in the absence of the HPOG 2.0 Program. 
The study has selected outcomes at specific follow-up time points to establish confirmatory hypotheses associated with its research questions. These hypotheses are in line with the program’s logic model and are important for informing practitioners and policymakers about career pathways programs. For the Short-Term Impact Report, educational progress is the confirmatory outcome. For the Intermediate-Term Impact Report, training completion within three years and earnings in the 12th quarter following randomization will both be confirmatory outcomes. For the Long-Term Impact Report, earnings at the 21st quarter following randomization is currently planned to be the sole confirmatory outcome. Across all time points, the study also will analyze a series of secondary and exploratory outcomes related to the program’s logic model. 
The study’s Cost-Benefit Analysis will estimate the costs of providing the HPOG 2.0 programs and will compare these costs with gains in employment and earnings measured in the impact study. The Cost-Benefit Analysis Report will assess the extent to which the benefits resulting from HPOG 2.0 programs exceed the costs of those programs. The cost-benefit report will use the HPOG 2.0 Impact Evaluation longer-term estimates (66-months) to estimate benefits and is scheduled for completion in Fall 2024.
The National Evaluation’s Descriptive Evaluation will include an Implementation Study, an Outcomes Study, and a Systems Study. A combined report on all three studies is scheduled for 2020.

q3.value:
This project investigates how people think about the temporal relation between two time intervals. There are logical systems such as Allen's Interval Calculus that break down the relations into a set of mutually exclusive categories. The subset of relations we focus on in the current experiment are: 

DURING: A[start]   B[start]   B[end]     A[end]
BEFORE:  A[start]   A[end]    B[start]    B[end]

The initial analysis of generated descriptions from an earlier experiment (DT1) suggest that descriptions rarely are complete and unambiguous. Additional experiments (DT2 and DT3) have shown that there is a chronological bias such that descriptions relating event start times are selected over descriptions that relate event end times in the majority of cases. There is evidence of a reverse chronological bias in one condition: intervals in which the events both started at the same time but ended at different times.

The current experiment is examining whether the preposition describing the relation ('before' or 'after’) affects the chronological bias. ‘Before' has been shown to be easier to process than ‘after’.  Viewed through mental model theory, ‘before’ statements align the order of mention with the chronological order of events along a timeline.  So if the download was before the recalibration, the timeline would be: [download] [recalibration].  But with 'after' the order is reversed; if the download was after the recalibration the timeline would be: [recalibration] [download]. ‘After' statements being more difficult is inline with the mental model theory, and here, may lead participants to scan their mental models in reverse chronological order.

Note: We will discuss the 8 individual conditions by referring to each condition in the following abbreviation: [Allen relation between the premises: during vs. before]/[The relation between when events start: before vs. after]/[The relation between when events end: before vs. after]. For example, in the following situation:

     A happened at 10am and ended at 2pm.
     B happened at 8am and ended at 4pm.

the premises reflect the relation in which A happens during B. One condition of the experiment investigates the following two conclusions:

     A started after B started.
     A ended before B ended.

Hence, the problem would be abbreviated as: during/after/before.

q4.value:
There is one condition that is a replication of a condition in DT2: During/Before/Before.  Therefore, for this condition, we have the specific prediction of again observing the chronological bias such that participants choose the response relating when events start over when they end.

We plan to do a full main effect and interaction analysis of the 2x2x2 design (3 main effects, 3 2-way interactions, 1 3-way interactions.  We do not predict a difference by Allen relation. The alternative hypotheses without regard for Allen relation are:
1. Main effect of the relation between when events start: There is a difference between 'before' and 'after'.
2. Main effect of the relation between when events end: There is a difference between 'before' and 'after'.
3. Interaction of the relations between when events starts and when events end: 'Before' and 'after' will affect the strength bias differently depending on which description type they are embedded within.

If using 'after' as the relation has an effect on response selection, we expect to get an interaction such that 'before' statements are more strongly preferred for relating when events start than for relating when events end. We expect this to be accompanied by a main effect of the relation between when events start such that descriptions using 'before' are selected more often than ones using 'after', a chronological bias.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The experiment has a 2 (Allen relations: before, during) x 2 (relation between when events start: after, before) x 2 (relation between when events end: after, before). There are 24 problems, 3 per condition.

Each problem consists of two computer/network events that occur on the same day.  Time intervals for each event are provided.  After a 2 second delay, participants are asked to choose which of 2 descriptions is better, one relating when the events start and one relating when the events end. For example:

The download started at 4am and ended at 7pm on Friday.
The recalibration started at 8pm and ended at 10pm on Friday.

Which of the following is a better description?
The recalibration ended after the download ended.
The download started before the recalibration ended.

There are 24 event labels that are each used twice in unique pairings. The times are randomly assigned.

q9.value: The order of all problems is randomized for each participant, as is the order of the event information, and the order of the conclusion statements.  The event labels are randomly assigned to problems with the restriction of not having the same pair assigned to a problem. The intervals are randomly generated within the defining confines of the Allen relation they represent.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The data will be collected through Amazon Mechanical Turk by a separate research firm, Knexus Research Corporation. They will handle payment and recruitment. Eligibility for the study includes native English speakers in the US who are above 18 years of age. The study will last approximately 15 minutes, and participants will be paid $2.00 for their participation.

q14.value: In DT2, the during relation (with before/before prepositions) was different from chance with an effect size of 0.35. Using a conservative effect size of 0.2, 0.05 alpha, and 0.80 power, 49 participants are needed according to G*Power's Exact, Proportion: Difference from constant test.

question.value:
Allen relation of the two events: before vs. during
Relation between when events start: after vs. before
Relation between when events end: after vs. before

For more detail, see Description and Design.

Preference between descriptions relating when events start vs. ones relating when events end.

We also collect demographic information: age, sex, language, and coursework in logic.

We will use non-parametric tests and linear mixed effects models to test the 2x2x2 design.
Main effects and 2 way interactions will be tested using Wilcoxon tests. The 3 way interaction will use a Friedman test. 
The linear mixed effects model will have fixed effects of the 3 factors (Allen relation, start times conclusion preposition, end times conclusion preposition) and their interactions.  The random effect of participant (intercept and random slopes by the fixed effects) will be included.  This is a complex model and non-convergence seems likely so a backward stepwise system will be used to get a converging model.  Post-hoc comparisons will be done using estimated marginal means.

q21.value: The alpha is 0.05.  The Šidák-Holm method of correction will be used for multiple comparisons for non-parametric tests.  The glmer algorithm and the emmean test correct for multiple comparisons in their output.

q22.value: Any participant who only clicks on one location (either always the first button or always the second button) will be excluded.  Additionally, if the debrief responses indicate that a participant did not do the task as instructed or are non-sense, the participant will be excluded.

q24.value: We will intend to explore whether any of the randomized variables affect the results including: the order of premises, the order of conclusions, the event labels, and the time interval between time points.  Also, we will explore whether any demographic variables change the key results.

registration_responses.q3:
This project investigates how people think about the temporal relation between two time intervals. There are logical systems such as Allen's Interval Calculus that break down the relations into a set of mutually exclusive categories. The subset of relations we focus on in the current experiment are: 

DURING: A[start]   B[start]   B[end]     A[end]
BEFORE:  A[start]   A[end]    B[start]    B[end]

The initial analysis of generated descriptions from an earlier experiment (DT1) suggest that descriptions rarely are complete and unambiguous. Additional experiments (DT2 and DT3) have shown that there is a chronological bias such that descriptions relating event start times are selected over descriptions that relate event end times in the majority of cases. There is evidence of a reverse chronological bias in one condition: intervals in which the events both started at the same time but ended at different times.

The current experiment is examining whether the preposition describing the relation ('before' or 'after’) affects the chronological bias. ‘Before' has been shown to be easier to process than ‘after’.  Viewed through mental model theory, ‘before’ statements align the order of mention with the chronological order of events along a timeline.  So if the download was before the recalibration, the timeline would be: [download] [recalibration].  But with 'after' the order is reversed; if the download was after the recalibration the timeline would be: [recalibration] [download]. ‘After' statements being more difficult is inline with the mental model theory, and here, may lead participants to scan their mental models in reverse chronological order.

Note: We will discuss the 8 individual conditions by referring to each condition in the following abbreviation: [Allen relation between the premises: during vs. before]/[The relation between when events start: before vs. after]/[The relation between when events end: before vs. after]. For example, in the following situation:

     A happened at 10am and ended at 2pm.
     B happened at 8am and ended at 4pm.

the premises reflect the relation in which A happens during B. One condition of the experiment investigates the following two conclusions:

     A started after B started.
     A ended before B ended.

Hence, the problem would be abbreviated as: during/after/before.
registration_responses.q4:
There is one condition that is a replication of a condition in DT2: During/Before/Before.  Therefore, for this condition, we have the specific prediction of again observing the chronological bias such that participants choose the response relating when events start over when they end.

We plan to do a full main effect and interaction analysis of the 2x2x2 design (3 main effects, 3 2-way interactions, 1 3-way interactions.  We do not predict a difference by Allen relation. The alternative hypotheses without regard for Allen relation are:
1. Main effect of the relation between when events start: There is a difference between 'before' and 'after'.
2. Main effect of the relation between when events end: There is a difference between 'before' and 'after'.
3. Interaction of the relations between when events starts and when events end: 'Before' and 'after' will affect the strength bias differently depending on which description type they are embedded within.

If using 'after' as the relation has an effect on response selection, we expect to get an interaction such that 'before' statements are more strongly preferred for relating when events start than for relating when events end. We expect this to be accompanied by a main effect of the relation between when events start such that descriptions using 'before' are selected more often than ones using 'after', a chronological bias.

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value: Notre étude dans son ensemble illustre un plan factoriel intersujets à trois variables indépendantes : 2 Film (triste vs. joyeux) x 2 Dissonance expressive (avec ‘ vs. sans) x 2 Consigne (affects instant présent vs. affects durant le film)

question2b.value:
1. Variable score de rappel d’informations correctes : 20 questions de reconnaissances sont proposées aux sujets, pour chacun des films proposés (Triste et Joyeux). Plus précisément il s’agit de 10 questions de type réponse unique à 5 modalités et de 10 questions de type vrai/faux. Dans les deux cas une modalité ‘ne sais pas’ est proposé. 

2. Variable échelle d'affects auto-rapportées : 20 items réparties en 4 sous-échelles (l'inconfort psychologique, l'affect négatif orienté vers le soi, l'anxiété et l'affect positif orientés vers le soi).  La consigne sera variable comme vu précédemment, et les individus devront se positionner sur une échelle de type Lickert en sept points (allant de (1) ne s'applique pas du tout à moi à (7) s'applique tout à fait à moi).

question10b.value: La procédure expérimentale de la recherche envisagée s’appuie sur celle de Robinson et Demaree (2007) et illustre un plan 2 (Dissonance Expressive : sans vs. avec) x 2 (Film : triste vs. joyeux) x 2 Consigne (affects instant présent vs. affects durant le film) intersujets. Elle est présentée comme suit. Les 256 participants recrutés sur le campus ALLSH d’AMU sont invités à s’asseoir dans le laboratoire face à un écran. L’expérimentateur leur décrit les tâches expérimentales : regarder deux films courts (2 minutes). Le premier film est émotionnellement neutre (Gross & Levenson, 1995) et a pour fonction d’habituer le participant au dispositif, comme c’est le cas dans les recherches de Robinson et Demaree (2007) et Pelt et al. (2018). Le second est un film pré-testé comme triste (vs. joyeux). Dans la moitié des conditions, les participants reçoivent la consigne de regarder ce film “naturellement, comme s’ils étaient assis devant la télé chez eux” (condition sans dissonance). Dans l’autre moitié, les participants reçoivent la consigne d’exprimer l’émotion opposée à celle ressentie. En d’autres mots, la consigne peut être présentée comme suit : « je [l’expérimentateur] souhaiterai que quelqu’un, qui vous regarde vous, pense que vous regardez un film joyeux (vs. triste)”. Après avoir regardé le film, les participants sont invités à répondre à une série de questions sur ce film, 10 questions en termes de vrai/faux et 10 questions de type réponse unique à 5 modalités (VD principale de dissonance expressive). Puis les participants sont invités à remplir une seconde échelle, l’échelle des affects auto-rapportées (Elliot & Devine, 1994), composées de 20 items, la consigne variant selon deux conditions. Une première condition propose une consigne mesurant les affects ressentis à l’instant t (« comment vous sentez vous à cet instant présent ? »), et la seconde une consigne mesurant les affects ressentis durant le visionnage du film (« comment vous vous sentiez lors du visionnage du film ? »). L’ensemble de la procédure prend environ 30 minutes.

question4b.value: Les 256 participants sont recrutés sur le campus Arts, Lettres, Langues et Sciences Humaines d'Aix-Marseille Université. Ils sont majoritairement recrutés directement dans la Licence 1 de Psychologie.

question5b.value: Une annonce auprès des étudiants de Licence 1 de psychologie du campus Arts, Lettres, Langues et Sciences Humaines d'Aix-Marseille Université sera faite. Ceux-ci pourront s’inscrire aux créneaux horaires proposés par l’expérimentatrice. Les passations seront faites en individuelles, après explicitation de la procédure par l’expérimentatrice. L’ensemble des données seront récoltés via logiciel informatique (Limesurvey).

question6b.value: L'objectif lors de l’analyse de puissance était d’obtenir une puissance de .95 pour détecter une taille d’effet moyen de .25 à la probabilité d’erreur alpha standard de .05, qui nous a donné une taille d’échantillon de 251. Dans un souci de parité des groupes nous l’avons fixé à 256.

question8b.value: Exclusion des données manquantes et des personnes de nationalité non française.

question9b.value: Il sera signalé aux participants qu’ils peuvent à tout moment arrêter l’expérience s’il le souhaite et directement sortir du laboratoire.

question6c.value: Comparaison deux à deux entre chacune des moyennes.

question1a.value:
H1 : On attend un meilleur rappel d’information en condition de dissonance expressive qu’en condition sans dissonance, quelle que soit la valence du film visionné. 

H2 : En condition avec dissonance expressive, on attend des scores d’affects négatifs orientés vers le soi plus élevés qu’en condition sans dissonance, quelle que soit la valence du film visionné.

H3 : En condition avec dissonance expressive, on attend des scores d’inconfort psychologique plus élevés qu’en condition sans dissonance, quelle que soit la valence du film visionné.

H4 : On attend des scores à l’échelle d’affects négatifs orientés vers le soi, plus élevés lorsque la consigne de complétion de l’échelle recentre le participant sur la phase d’éveil de dissonance (les affects ressentis pendant le visionnage du film).

H5 : On attend des scores à l’échelle d’inconfort psychologique plus élevés lorsque la consigne de complétion de l’échelle recentre le participant sur la phase d’éveil de dissonance (les affects ressentis pendant le visionnage du film).

question2a.value: Notre étude dans son ensemble illustre un plan factoriel intersujets à trois variables indépendantes : 2 Film (triste vs. joyeux) x 2 Dissonance expressive (avec vs. sans) x 2 Consigne (affects instant présent vs. affects durant le film)

question3a.value:
Concernant notre variable Film, nous nous appuyons sur des séquences de film étudiées par Schaefer, Nils, Sanchez et Philippot (2010). Cela nous a permis de présélectionner des films induisant l’émotion cible (joie ‘The dinner game’ et tristesse ‘Dangerous Mind’) dans une population francophone. Ces séquences sont efficaces concernant les émotions discrètes : elles permettent de différencier les émotions. Nous avons pré-testé les deux films sélectionnés auprès de notre population cible. Nous avons également pris le soin de pré-tester nos questionnaires de connaissances concernant ces deux films.

Pour manipuler notre variable Dissonance, nous manipulons la consigne expérimentale d’introduction du film (triste et joyeux). Pour la formulation de nos deux consignes (avec et sans dissonance expressive), nous nous appuyons notamment sur les deux études (Robinson et Demaree, 2007 et Pelt, Barbier et Fointiat, 2018) ayant testé cette variable dans le cadre de la dissonance expressive. Les consignes ont ainsi pu être formulée comme suit : 
-	Condition avec dissonance : « regardez le film en exprimant l’émotion opposée à celle que vous ressentez, c’est-à-dire de sorte qu’une personne qui vous regarde vous pense que vous regardez un film triste s’il est joyeux (un film joyeux s’il est triste) »  
-	Condition sans dissonance : « regardez le film de manière naturelle, comme si vous étiez chez vous devant la télé ». 

Enfin, concernant la consigne de l’échelle d’affect, nous nous appuyons ici sur l’étude de Cancino-Montecinos et al. (2018). Les chercheurs ont ici fait varier la consigne d’introduction d’une échelle des émotions différentes, le PANAS. Cependant, cette hypothèse étant secondaire dans notre recherche nous n’avons pas nécessité de pré-tester cette variable. Les résultats serviront de pré-test pour des études à suivre concernant la dissonance expressive.

question5a.value: A notre connaissance, seules deux études ont envisagé dans une approche expérimentale qu’un état de dissonance pouvait être induit par une inconsistance émotionnelle : les recherches de Robinson et Demaree (2007) et de Pelt, Barbier et Fointiat (2018). Ces auteurs parlent alors de dissonance expressive, qui est définie comme “le fait d’exprimer facialement l’opposé de ce que l’on ressent” (e.g., sourire alors qu’on se sent triste, Robinson et Demaree, 2007, p.71). Notre étude s’inscrit dans cette approche expérimentale et vise à explorer les composantes de la dissonance expressive. Cela, en reproduisant les effets de dissonance expressif afin d’en vérifier la robustesse.

question1c.value:
Les scores de rappel seront attribués selon deux possibilités : ‘1’ pour les réponses justes et ‘0’ pour les réponses fausses. Une moyenne totale sera faite.

Les scores d’affects seront calculées en fonction des quatre sous-échelles établies. Une moyenne des différents items d’affects sera calculée selon leur sous-échelle d’appartenance, le score pouvant aller de ‘1’ (ne s'applique pas du tout à moi) à ‘7 (s'applique tout à fait à moi).

question2c.value: Les données seront traitées par une ANOVA.

question3c.value:
VI : Film, Consigne Film (Dissonance), Consigne échelle d’affects.
VD : Echelle d’affects, Rappel d’informations correctes.

registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: Les 256 participants sont recrutés sur le campus Arts, Lettres, Langues et Sciences Humaines d'Aix-Marseille Université. Ils sont majoritairement recrutés directement dans la Licence 1 de Psychologie.

Une annonce auprès des étudiants de Licence 1 de psychologie du campus Arts, Lettres, Langues et Sciences Humaines d'Aix-Marseille Université sera faite. Ceux-ci pourront s’inscrire aux créneaux horaires proposés par l’expérimentatrice. Les passations seront faites en individuelles, après explicitation de la procédure par l’expérimentatrice. L’ensemble des données seront récoltés via logiciel informatique (Limesurvey).

L'objectif lors de l’analyse de puissance était d’obtenir une puissance de .95 pour détecter une taille d’effet moyen de .25 à la probabilité d’erreur alpha standard de .05, qui nous a donné une taille d’échantillon de 251. Dans un souci de parité des groupes nous l’avons fixé à 256.
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q: Exclusion des données manquantes et des personnes de nationalité non française.

attributes.title: The Association Between Vision Impairment and Mortality: Protocol for a Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis

summary.value:
The Association Between Vision Impairment and Mortality: Protocol for a Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis

Authors
Joshua R. Ehrlich, Jacqueline Ramke, David Macleod, Bonnielin K. Swenor, Helen Burn, Chan Ning Lee, William Waldock, Justine H. Zhang, Iris Gordon, Nathan Congdon, Matthew Burton, Jennifer R. Evans

Description
Vision impairment (VI) and blindness affect more than one-quarter of a billion people worldwide.[1] Due to population growth and aging, the number of affected individuals is projected to grow even larger. VI and blindness are associated with adverse health outcomes, including dementia and cognitive decline, depression, falls, and low of independence. A prior systematic review and meta-analysis published in 2016 by Zhang et al found that the risk of mortality was elevated among those with VI.[2] However, there were several important limitations to that study. Briefly, the study by Zhang et al did not assess the risk of bias in included studies or certainty of the evidence; it pooled results from studies that used objectively measured VI, self-reported VI, and VI defined by diagnostic billing codes; and it did not include search terms relevant to specific common eye conditions. Moreover, in recent years studies on VI and mortality risk have been published in regions of the world that were not well-represented in the prior systematic review. Accordingly, this protocol describes an updated systematic review and meta-analysis of the effect of VI on the risk of mortality, including an assessment of the risk of bias in included studies and an evaluation of the certainty of the evidence. The results of this study will make an important contribution to global eye health. Results will be included in the ongoing Lancet Global Health Commission on Global Eye Health [3] and will be published in the peer-reviewed literature.

Review Questions
1.	What is the extent, strength, and quality of the published evidence that VI is associated with the risk of all-cause mortality? 
2.	To what degree does VI affect the risk of all-cause mortality, and does this risk vary based on level of visual function?

Study Design
Systematic review and meta-analysis of published studies.

Inclusion Criteria
•	Prospective and retrospective cohort studies;
•	Baseline assessment of vision (exposure) using an objective quantitative clinical or research assessment;
•	Longitudinal assessment of all-cause mortality (outcome) over at least 1 year;
•	Reports age-adjusted estimate of the effect of VI on mortality risk;
•	Peer-reviewed published articles in English.

Exclusion criteria
•	Interventional studies;
•	Studies where all participants had a specific systemic disease (e.g. diabetes);
•	VI self-reported or defined using diagnostic billing codes;
•	Grey literature or conference abstracts.

Participants: Men and women age 40 years and older at study baseline.

Exposure
Visual function must have been measured using an objective quantitative clinical or research instrument; this may include, but is not limited to: visual acuity, visual fields, stereoacuity, and contrast sensitivity. Categories of VI using visual acuity will be based on the WHO International Classification of Diseases.[4] For other vision tests, we will use study-specific definitions of VI since standard definitions are not commonly employed. When available, we will also consider continuous measures of vision (e.g. logMAR visual acuity) in analyses.

Outcome
The outcome of interest is all-cause mortality one or more years after baseline assessment of vision. We will consider mortality assessed by any method (e.g. vital records, informant report), since we aim to include studies from all geographic regions and vital records are rarely available in some settings.

Effect Measures
To determine the risk of mortality associated with VI, we will compile age-adjusted measures of effect from each included study. When possible we will choose measures that are also adjusted for theoretical confounders of the association between VI and mortality, such as smoking status and socioeconomics. We will also seek to avoid measures of effect that are adjusted for theoretical mediators, including overall health and functional status.

Search Methods
We will search MEDLINE Ovid, Embase Ovid, and Global Health. There will be no limits on date of publication. As noted above, English language peer-reviewed articles will be considered; conference abstracts and grey literature will not be included. See the attached document (SearchStrategy.pdf) for the complete search strategy used in MEDLINE Ovid.

Selection of Studies and Data Extraction
Two reviewers will independently screen abstracts and titles to remove reports that are not eligible for this review. A third reviewer will arbitrate any disagreements. Next, full texts will be reviewed by two reviewers to determine if studies meet all inclusion and exclusion criteria. Again, disagreements will be arbitrated by a third reviewer. Data extraction will be guided by the CHecklist for critical Appraisal and data extraction for Systematic Reviews of prediction Modelling Studies (CHARMS) checklist.[5] Two review authors will independently extract the following data from each included study: study design, participant characteristics, study population and size, study setting, study dates, follow-up duration, diagnostic and ascertainment methods, study attrition, estimates of effect size, and standard error. We will seek summary measures of the effect of VI on the risk of mortality; we anticipate that these will be reported as hazard ratios, risk ratios, rate ratios, standardized mortality ratios, cumulative incidence rates, proportions, survival curves, and/or odds ratios. Standard errors and/or 95% confidence intervals will be sought for all estimates. If disagreements between reviewers cannot be resolved, a third reviewer will arbitrate. Selection of studies, data extraction, and data management will be conducted using Covidence systematic review software (Veritas Health Innovation, Melbourne, Australia; available at www.covidence.org).

Bias Assessment
Risk of bias will be independently assessed by two reviewers using the Quality in Prognostic Studies (QUIPS) tool.[7] Domains that will be assessed include: study participation, attrition, prognostic factor measurement, outcome measurement, and confounding. We will assign an overall risk of bias based on ratings in each domain; only studies rates as having a low risk of bias will receive an overall “low” rating and any study with at least one domain rated “high” will receive an overall high rating.

Data Analysis
    Heterogeneity: We will assess clinical heterogeneity based on characteristics, including age, sex, and ocular diagnosis. We will also assess methodological heterogeneity (e.g. comparing risk of bias across included studies), while statistical heterogeneity will be appraised by inspection of I-squared and Tau-squared statistics. Publication bias will be assessed using a funnel plot. 

    Data synthesis/Meta-Analysis: The meta-analysis will follow guidelines of the Meta-analysis Of Observational Studies in Epidemiology (MOOSE) checklist.[6] We will employ a random-effects model with generic inverse variance. Results from the meta-analysis will be summarised with pooled estimates and 95% confidence intervals, as well as between study variance (Tau-squared). We will analyse effect estimates separately for the different types of effect measures (e.g. hazard ratios, odds ratios, and risk ratios). The overall quality of evidence from our meta-analysis will be reported using the modified Grades of Recommendation, Assessment, Development, and Evaluation (GRADE) tool.[7]

    Meta-regression and Sensitivity Analysis: Using random-effects meta-regression we will assess the relationship between the following covariates and effect size: sex, average age, method of vision assessment, follow-up duration, and Global Burden of Disease Study super-region.[8] Sensitivity analyses will be performed excluding studies with an overall “high” risk of bias rating.

This systematic review and meta-analysis will be reported in accordance with the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis (PRISMA) checklist.[9]

References
1 	World Report on Vision. Geneva: World Health Organization 2019. CC BY-NC-SA 3.0 IGO
2 	Zhang T, Jiang W, Song X, et al. The association between visual impairment and the risk of mortality: a meta-analysis of prospective studies. J Epidemiol Community Health 2016;70:836–42. doi:10.1136/jech-2016-207331
3 	Burton MJ, Faal HB, Ramke J, et al. Announcing The Lancet Global Health Commission on Global Eye Health. Lancet Glob Health 2019;7:e1612–3. doi:10.1016/S2214-109X(19)30450-4
4 	World Health Organization. International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health. 1st ed. Geneva, Switzerland: : World Health Organization 2001. 
5 	Moons KGM, Groot JAH de, Bouwmeester W, et al. Critical Appraisal and Data Extraction for Systematic Reviews of Prediction Modelling Studies: The CHARMS Checklist. PLOS Medicine 2014;11:e1001744. doi:10.1371/journal.pmed.1001744
6 	Stroup DF, Berlin JA, Morton SC, et al. Meta-analysis of observational studies in epidemiology: a proposal for reporting. Meta-analysis Of Observational Studies in Epidemiology (MOOSE) group. JAMA 2000;283:2008–12. doi:10.1001/jama.283.15.2008
7 	Iorio A, Spencer FA, Falavigna M, et al. Use of GRADE for assessment of evidence about prognosis: rating confidence in estimates of event rates in broad categories of patients. BMJ 2015;350:h870. doi:10.1136/bmj.h870
8 	GBD 2017 DALYs and HALE Collaborators. Global, regional, and national disability-adjusted life-years (DALYs) for 359 diseases and injuries and healthy life expectancy (HALE) for 195 countries and territories, 1990-2017: a systematic analysis for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2017. Lancet 2018;392:1859–922. doi:10.1016/S0140-6736(18)32335-3
9 	Moher D, Liberati A, Tetzlaff J, et al. Preferred reporting items for systematic reviews and meta-analyses: the PRISMA statement. PLoS Med 2009;6:e1000097. doi:10.1371/journal.pmed.1000097

attributes.title: Supplemental materials for preprint: IMPLEMENTASI PENDEKATAN SAINTIFIK DENGAN MENGGUNAKAN MODEL POE2WE UNTUK MELATIH LITERASI SAINTIFIK DAN MENINGKATKAN HASIL BELAJAR SISWA DALAM DOMAIN KOMPETENSI PADA TOPIK GERAK LURUS
attributes.description: Penelitian ini bertujuan untuk mengetahui dan menganalisis perbedaan antara siswa yang mendapatkan pembelajaran dengan pendekatan saintifik melalui model POE2WE ini dan menerapkan pendekatan saintifik untuk melatih literasi saintifik dengan siswa yang mendapatkan pembelajaran. Metode atau pendekatan yang digunakan dalam tulisan ini menggunakan metode atau pendekatan kepustakaan (library research), sedangkan pengumpulan data dilakukan dengan menelaah dan/atau mengekplorasi beberapa Jurnal, buku, dan dokumen-dokumen (baik yang berbentuk cetak maupun elektronik) serta sumber-sumber data dan atau informasi lainnya yang dianggap relevan dengan kajian. Temuan dalam kajian ini adalah pelaksanaan pembelajaran dengan menggunakan pendekatan saintifik melalui model POE2WE terlaksana dengan baik sehingga terdapat peningkatan hasil belajar pada siswa dalam materi gerak lurus yang dapat dilihat dari hasil nilai pre-test dan post-test siswa. Selain itu siswa juga mengalami peningkatan yang signifikan dengan menggunakan pendekatan saintifik karena dapat melatihkan siswa dalam literasi saintifik. Dengan demikian, desain pembelajaran yang dirancang pada penelitian ini dengan pendekatan saintifik untuk melatihkan literasi saintifik pada topik gerak lurus dapat ikut serta memperkaya kajian keilmuan pembelajaran Fisika di sekolah menengah.

Kedua, data pustaka bersifat “siap pakai” artinya peniliti tidak terjung langsung kelapangan karena peneliti berhadapan langsung dengan sumber data yang ada di perpustakaan. registration_responses.q12.question: Dalam penelitian studi pustaka setidaknya ada empat ciri utama yang penulis perlu perhatikan diantaranya : Pertama, bahwa penulis atau peneliti berhadapan langsung dengan teks (nash) atau data angka, bukan dengan pengetahuan langsung dari lapangan. Kedua, data pustaka bersifat “siap pakai” artinya peniliti tidak terjung langsung kelapangan karena peneliti berhadapan langsung dengan sumber data yang ada di perpustakaan. Ketiga, bahwa data pustaka umumnya adalah sumber sekunder, dalam arti bahwa peneliti memperoleh bahan atau data dari tangan kedua dan bukan data orisinil dari data pertama di lapangan. Keempat, bahwa kondisi data pustaka tidak dibatasi oleh ruang dan waktu
registration_responses.q17.question: bahwa hasil tes akhir bagi peserta didik kelompok eksperimen dan kontrol terdapat perbedaan yang signifikan (p<0,05). Jadi terdapat perbedaan yang signifikan hasil tes akhir antara peserta didik yang diajar dengan pendekatan saintifik melalui model POE2WE dengan pendekatan saintifik saja. Kesimpulannya model POE2WE efektif digunakan untuk meningkatkan prestasi belajar peserta didik pada mata pelajaran Fisika di SMA. Hasil analisis setelah diuji Paired Sampel t-test hasilnya terdapat perbedaan. Hal ini membuktikan bahwa hasil belajar kognitif sebelum dan setelah diterapkan model POE2WE. Terdapat kenaikan hasil belajar kognitif siswa, yang dapat dilihat dari nilai rata – rata siswa saat pretes dan postes. Nilai pretest dan posttest tersebut kemudian dihitung tingkat kenaikan hasil belajarnya untuk menetahui efektivitasnya. Rumus yang digunakan adalah N-gain ternormalisasi

attributes.title: The joint flanker effect in preschool children

q1.value: Joint flanker effect with the co-actor sharing the task rule in preschool children

q3.value:
In the joint flanker task, one of the two targets appears in the center of the screen and flankers either identical to (i.e., the compatible trials) or different from (i.e., the incompatible trials) it appear in the both sides in a row. Participants respond to one target while the co-actor responds to the other. The difference in reaction time between the compatible and the incompatible trials is greater in the joint situation as compared to isolation, which is called “the joint flanker effect” (Atmaca, Sebanz, & Knoblich, 2011; Dolk, Hommel, Prinz & Liepelt, 2014). In our prior experiment, we examined whether we could observe this joint flanker effect in preschool children. 
Atmaca et al. (2011) suggests the social account that representations about the co-actor’s responses may interfere with participants’ response-selection. If so, participants should take longer reaction time in the incompatible trials as compared to the case where participants performed the task alone. However, their results showed facilitation effects in the compatible trials in the joint situation compared to isolation and little differences between the situations in the incompatible trials. One possible interpretation for the little differences in the incompatible trials was that social facilitation or greater motivation in the social context cancels out the interference from the co-actor’s-action-relevant flankers in the incompatible trials. We aim to examine whether cost in the incompatible trials is occurred by Atmaca et al. (2011)’s social account in young children.
To this end, we will conduct an experiment, where participants respond to the same target with the co-actor, hence sharing the task rule. We will use the color version flanker paradigm for young children (McDermott, Pérez-Edgar, & Fox, 2007), the same paradigm as our prior experiment. Two colors (i.e., blue and red) will be used. Participants will be given two conditions: the single condition and the joint condition. In the single condition, participants will be required to respond with a key when one color (e.g., blue) is presented as the target while they will inhibit their response when the other color (e.g., red) appears as the target. In the joint condition, one color (e.g., blue) will be assigned both to participants and the co-actor. Thus, participants and the co-actor will respond when their assigned color appears and inhibit their response when the other appears. 
For examining the effects of the joint action on response competition, we measure reaction time for the target display and accuracy in the single and joint conditions respectively.

q4.value: We hypothesize that the joint flanker effect is caused by participants’ representations about the co-actor’s responses which interfere with participants’ response-selection as Atmaca et al. (2011) proposed. When the co-actor responds to the same target as participants respond to, the flanker in the incompatible trials does not correspond to the co-actor’s response. Considering the social account, there should be no interference in the incompatible trials in this case. Hence, we predict that the incompatible trials as well as the compatible trials should show shorter reaction time in the joint condition as compared to the single condition with social facilitation solely affecting.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We have two within-subject factors, rule (the single condition and the joint condition) and compatibility (the compatible trials and the incompatible trials).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited in the kindergarten or through the university’s database. Participants’ age will be ranged from four to six.

q13.value: Our target sample size for the analyses is 40 participants.

q14.value: We determine our sample size based on our prior experiment (https://osf.io/zdxta).

question.value: Participants will perform the task with an adult experimenter. They will jointly attend to the display and respond to the target in accordance with the color of the target with the experimenter in the joint condition whereas they will perform the task with the experimenter who does not provide any action in the single condition. We will manipulate the compatibility for the target-flanker colors in the display. The two levels of this categorical variable are: the compatible trials and the incompatible trials. The task consists of two conditions: the single condition and the joint condition.
We will measure reaction time and accuracy in the flanker task.

We will use a two-way ANOVA. The independent variables are rule (the single rule vs. the joint rule) and compatibility (the compatible trials vs the incompatible trials) and the dependent variable is reaction time. We will test whether the compatible trials as well as the incompatible trials shows shorter reaction time for the joint condition than the single condition.
As for accuracy, we will do the same analyses as reaction time to examine the possibility of speed-accuracy trade-off and fatigue effect.

q21.value: We will use 0.05 significance level for the p-values.

q22.value: We will exclude the data of the participants, who do not complete the task or whose performance is extremely low (i.e., low accuracy).

q24.value: We may conduct additional exploratory analyses not specified above.

q3.value:
Agenda cueing is a low-effort agenda-setting mechanism in a dual-process model developed by Pingree and Stoycheff (2013). It occurs when individuals view perceived media agenda as a reflection of journalists' issue importance judgments, and use this cue in forming their own most important issue response. Agenda cue uptake can occur regardless of actual exposure to the substantive content of media coverage. Later work applied the same logic to Twitter agenda, where social media users were the source of an agenda cue (Stoycheff et al. 2018).

All experimental agenda cueing studies to date used a highly specific stimulus: a summary report of last week's media or Twitter coverage that showed what share of the overall number of publications or posts the most covered topics received. This allowed researchers to isolate the agenda cue from the coverage itself, making sure that it is not engaging with the content that influences respondents' issue prioritization. However, this format of treatment carries a potential validity threat. It is possible that the powerful agenda-setting effects of such cues that these studies reported were due to the "distilled" character of the treatment. It is not clear whether news consumers can actually pick up agenda cues in high-choice digital media environments for themselves.

Instead of coverage summary reports, this study uses a series of realistic news portal screenshots where headlines are not be clickable, thus remedying methodological shortcomings of previous studies related to the nature of stimuli. Agency cues embedded in the newsfeed interface attribute its curation to either news media ("Top stories") or peers ("Most clicked"/"Recommended by users") to test the expectation of differential effects of agenda cues coming from different gatekeepers. Moderating effects of respective media literacy constructs, media gatekeeping trust and social gatekeeping trust, will be tested.

q4.value:
H1: The presence of a problem in agenda cues from a) news media; b) other users, in the form of a popularity indicator; c) other users, in a form of explicit recommendation, will increase problem importance judgments.
H2: The presence of agenda cues from news media will increase problem importance judgments more among those with higher news gatekeeping trust.
H3: The presence of agenda cues from a) other users, in the form of a popularity indicator; b) other users, in a form of explicit recommendation will increase problem importance judgments more among those with higher social gatekeeping trust.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The study is designed as a 2 (Emphasized issue 1: Abortion/Drugs) X 2 (Emphasized issue 2: Cybersecurity/AI regulation) X 3 (Source of the cue: News media/Other users - most viewed/Other users - recommended as important) fully factorial, between-subjects experiment. Issues are emphasized by both prominence and frequency of appearance in the newsfeed.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Study participants will be recruited via Amazon Mechanical Turk. They will be paid $1 upon completion of the procedure and accompanying survey. Participants must be at least 18 years old and reside in the United States.

q13.value: The initial sample size will be 1070 participants, however i anticipate that some of the responses will have to be discarded (e.g. those whose timing has been significantly faster than the mean).

q14.value: 1070 is the maximum amount possible given budgetary constraints. According to power analysis, this sample size should be sufficient to detect effects with sizes upwards of 0.16. This is a reasonable effect size given that previous agenda cueing studies have consistently found fairly strong effects.

question.value:
Each participant will see three screenshots of the general newsfeed, followed by three screenshots of the feed with technology-related news. In the general newsfeed, the coverage of the emphasized problem will be prominently featured and the coverage of the deemphasized problem will be absent. In the technology-specific feed, the coverage of both stories will be present, with stories on the emphasized issue ranked higher than stories on the deemphasized issue. The following variables will be manipulated:
1. Issue emphasized in the general feed, nominal, two levels: Abortion or Drugs;
2. Issue emphasized in the general feed, nominal, two levels: AI regulation/ethics over Cybersecurity or Cybersecurity over AI regulation/ethics.
3. Source of the agenda cue, three levels: Top stories/Most viewed/Recommended.

Outcome measures: 
1. Perceived most important problem, open-ended. Two variations:
a) What do you think are the most important problems facing the nation? Please list them in order of importance, starting with the most important problem;
b) What do you think are the most important problems in the field of technology right now? Please list them in order of importance, starting with the most important problem.
 
The issue importance scores will then be calculated by dividing the issue’s reverse response position by the total number of issues mentioned. As a result, regardless of the total number of issues mentioned, the problem mentioned first will receive the importance score of 1; if a respondent does not mention the issue at all, its importance score will be 0; if it is mentioned halfway through the list of several problems, it will be coded as 0.50. For instance, if drugs is mentioned last in a list of three problems, its importance score would be 0.33; if “opioid crisis” is listed last in a list of five problems, drugs would receive a score of 0.20.

Manipulation checks:
1. Portal comprehensiveness
•	The news portal was a comprehensive source of the news of the day (0=Strongly disagree, 10=Strongly agree)
•	The portal covered as broad a range of news as established online news aggregators (0=Strongly disagree, 10=Strongly agree)
•	If this was a real portal, I would likely use it as a source of daily news (0=Strongly disagree, 10=Strongly agree)
2. Perceived agendas (open-ended)
•	Judging by the coverage featured in the news portal, what problems were mainstream media most concerned with last week?
•	Judging by the coverage featured in the portal, what problems were online news readers most concerned with last week?
3. Pre-test problem importance, closed-ended.
•	“What do you think is the most important problem facing the country today?” (Gap between rich and poor; Unemployment/jobs; Federal debt; Taxes; Wage issues; Foreign trade; Corporate corruption; Poor leadership; Immigration; Healthcare; Poverty/Homelessness; Environment/Climate change; Race relations/Racism; Guns/Gun control; Abortion; Education; Drugs; Crime; Welfare; Terrorism)

Mediators
1. Gatekeeping trust
•	News outlets choose which stories to cover by carefully deciding which issues or problems are the most important in society (0=Strongly disagree, 10=Strongly agree)
•	When deciding how much time to spend covering each issue, reporters and editors are thinking mostly about how important each issue is in society (0=Strongly disagree, 10=Strongly agree)
•	When the news gives some topic a lot of coverage, it means they’ve decided it’s a really important issue in society (0=Strongly disagree, 10=Strongly agree)
•	The top stories in a TV newscast are usually about whatever issues the editors think are the most serious, urgent or widespread in society (0=Strongly disagree, 10=Strongly agree)
•	You can trust that when there are problems in society that really are urgent and important, the news will make a big deal out of them (0=Strongly disagree, 10=Strongly agree)
The items will be combined into a scale; a dichotomous variable (high/low) will be created for the purpose of statistical analyses.
2. Social gatekeeping trust
•	You can trust that when there is a problem in society that is really urgent and important, people will pay a great deal of attention to it online (0=Strongly disagree, 10=Strongly agree)
•	Even when you don’t follow politics and current events, you can trust that others will bring important issues to your attention on the internet (0=Strongly disagree, 10=Strongly agree)
•	When a lot of people read and talk about a political issue online, it means people think that issue is more important than other issues (0=Strongly disagree, 10=Strongly agree)
•	When people read news on the internet, the problem to which they pay the most attention is usually the one that they think is really serious, urgent, or widespread in society (0=Strongly disagree, 10=Strongly agree)
The items will be combined into a scale; a dichotomous variable (high/low) will be created for the purpose of statistical analyses.
Covariates
1. General media trust
•	In general, mainstream news outlets are fair (1=Strongly disagree, 7=Strongly agree)
•	In general, mainstream news outlets are accurate (1=Strongly disagree, 7=Strongly agree)
•	In general, mainstream news outlets are unbiased (1=Strongly disagree, 7=Strongly agree)
•	In general, mainstream news outlets tell the whole story (1=Strongly disagree, 7=Strongly agree)
•	In general, mainstream news outlets can be trusted (1=Strongly disagree, 7=Strongly agree)
The items will be combined into a scale; a dichotomous variable (high/low) will be created for the purpose of statistical analyses.

In order to estimate the effects of agenda cues on participants' perceptions of issue importance, I will estimate  ANOVA models with the difference between importance scores of the emphasized and deemphasized problems as an outcome, separately for the general and technology-specific responses. I will include the following factors in the models : 1) emphasized issue; 2) source of the agenda cue and 3) dichotomous gatekeeping trust/social gatekeeping trust. If  gatekeeping trust proves to be a significant moderator of agenda cueing effects, i will also estimate ANCOVA models with general media trust as a covariate in order to validate that the effect is specific to gatekeeping trust and not explained by the more general media trust construct.

q20.value: The items measuring general media trust, gatekeeping trust and social gatekeeing trust will be combined into respective indices. For the purposes of statistical analysis, these indices will be transformed into dummy variables (low/high).

q21.value: I will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the post-hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. The post-hoc Bonferroni test will adjust for multiple comparisons.

q22.value: Responses by participants whose response time was significantly lower than the mean will be excluded from analysis.

q23.value: If a participant does not respond to both issue importance questions, they will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value: I expect that political ideology and interest in political affairs could be related to issue importance perceptions. Hence, I will look for relationships between these variables and the primary outcome measures of issue importance.

•	You can trust that when there are problems in society that really are urgent and important, the news will make a big deal out of them (0=Strongly disagree, 10=Strongly agree)
The items will be combined into a scale; a dichotomous variable (high/low) will be created for the purpose of statistical analyses.
2. Social gatekeeping trust
•	You can trust that when there is a problem in society that is really urgent and important, people will pay a great deal of attention to it online (0=Strongly disagree, 10=Strongly agree)
•	Even when you don’t follow politics and current events, you can trust that others will bring important issues to your attention on the internet (0=Strongly disagree, 10=Strongly agree)
•	When a lot of people read and talk about a political issue online, it means people think that issue is more important than other issues (0=Strongly disagree, 10=Strongly agree)
•	When people read news on the internet, the problem to which they pay the most attention is usually the one that they think is really serious, urgent, or widespread in society (0=Strongly disagree, 10=Strongly agree)
The items will be combined into a scale; a dichotomous variable (high/low) will be created for the purpose of statistical analyses.
Covariates
1. General media trust
•	In general, mainstream news outlets are fair (1=Strongly disagree, 7=Strongly agree)
•	In general, mainstream news outlets are accurate (1=Strongly disagree, 7=Strongly agree)
•	In general, mainstream news outlets are unbiased (1=Strongly disagree, 7=Strongly agree)
•	In general, mainstream news outlets tell the whole story (1=Strongly disagree, 7=Strongly agree)
•	In general, mainstream news outlets can be trusted (1=Strongly disagree, 7=Strongly agree)
The items will be combined into a scale; a dichotomous variable (high/low) will be created for the purpose of statistical analyses.
registration_responses.q19.question: In order to estimate the effects of agenda cues on participants' perceptions of issue importance, I will estimate  ANOVA models with the difference between importance scores of the emphasized and deemphasized problems as an outcome, separately for the general and technology-specific responses. I will include the following factors in the models : 1) emphasized issue; 2) source of the agenda cue and 3) dichotomous gatekeeping trust/social gatekeeping trust. If  gatekeeping trust proves to be a significant moderator of agenda cueing effects, i will also estimate ANCOVA models with general media trust as a covariate in order to validate that the effect is specific to gatekeeping trust and not explained by the more general media trust construct.
